articles.headline: Snooping in the Bathroom to Assess Credit Risk in China
articles.snippet: Extensive consumer databases are not in place for lenders to check, but companies are scrambling to crack the credit code.
articles.abstract: Extensive consumer databases are not in place for lenders to check, but companies are scrambling to crack the credit code.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUNSHAN, China — Banks and other lenders typically look at borrowers’ credit histories, tax forms and other financial information to determine whether they will get paid back. In China, lenders also look at their bathrooms.

articles.headline: Were He Seeking Any Other Job, Trump Would Be Flagged by H.R.
articles.snippet: Recordings of his vulgar boasts would make the Republican nominee a major legal liability, and many companies consider such language a firing offense.
articles.abstract: Recordings of his vulgar boasts would make the Republican nominee a major legal liability, and many companies consider such language a firing offense.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump describes himself as a businessman. And he says he wants to run the government more like a business.

articles.headline: Twitter Is Said to Be in Continued Talks With Salesforce
articles.snippet: The company tries to forge ahead despite a constantly shifting chess match of deal discussions and considerations.
articles.abstract: The company tries to forge ahead despite a constantly shifting chess match of deal discussions and considerations.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the last week, Twitter’s fate has appeared to be murkier than ever. The troubled social media company, which has been engaged in talks to sell itself, seemed to be running out of potential buyers.

articles.headline: For Many Women, Trump’s ‘Locker Room Talk’ Brings Memories of Abuse
articles.snippet: When she first posted a message on Twitter, Kelly Oxford, a social media powerhouse, didn’t expect many replies. She got millions.
articles.abstract: When she first posted a message on Twitter, Kelly Oxford, a social media powerhouse, didn’t expect many replies. She got millions.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the author Kelly Oxford, a social media powerhouse, who got things started on Friday night.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton’s Campaign Strained to Hone Her Message, Hacked Emails Show
articles.snippet: Thousands of messages released by WikiLeaks offered a look inside an operation that misread the electoral mood, throwing Mrs. Clinton’s campaign off course.
articles.abstract: Thousands of messages released by WikiLeaks offered a look inside an operation that misread the electoral mood, throwing Mrs. Clinton’s campaign off course.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the eve of the New Hampshire primary in February, a longtime aide to Bill Clinton was worried. Hillary Clinton was about to go down to defeat in the state, and the former president was despondent.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: Why Samsung Abandoned Its Galaxy Note 7 Flagship Phone
articles.snippet: The unprecedented move by the South Korean electronics giant is an embarrassing reversal for a respected global brand.
articles.abstract: The unprecedented move by the South Korean electronics giant is an embarrassing reversal for a respected global brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: When several Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphones spontaneously exploded in August, the South Korean company went into overdrive. It urged hundreds of employees to quickly diagnose the problem.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Choe Sang-Hun
